title: Philosophy: What is C.S. Peirce's pragmatism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q. Philosophy: What is Charles Sanders Peirce’s Pragmatism?  Above: Peirce (1) Short answer: “Act as if what you do makes a difference” (2) Here’s the ‘Pragmatism’ philosophy of Charles Sanders Peirce and William James, simply put. If you’re lost in a forest, and you see a path, you can believe one of 2 possibilities.That the path leads nowhereSo, you do nothing, stay lost, starve and die.Your action has made your beliefs come true.That the path leads to food and shelterSo, you follow it, and find a way out of the shithole to safety.Your action has made your beliefs come true.Act as if what you do makes a difference (3) Which is the largest group of practioners of this philosophy in the world?  Technologists?Scientists?Diplomats?Politicians?Surprise, surprise! Religious people. Religious belief can bring about extraordinary changes in people’s lives,such as the healing of the sick at pilgrimage sites.This occurs regardless of whether or not a god actually exists. (4) Here’s an application of pragmatism. A woman’s husband has gone missing. The woman, accompanied by a friend, went to the police station to report the disappearance. Police: Describe your husband. Woman: He’s 6 feet, well-built, lean, thick hair. Friend: What’re you talking about? Your husband is five feet four, bald, has a huge belly. Woman: Who wants that one back?

His theory is basically a principle of inquiry and account of meaning. "Consider what effects that might conceivably have practical bearings you conceive the objects of your conception to have. Then, your conception of those effects is the whole of your conception of the object."
